caption: I went to Paris specifically to see my favourite musical, Les Mis√©rables at the Chatalet Theatre, but before I did that I simply had to visit the home of Victor Hugo, the author of Notre-Dame de Paris (or The Hunchback of Notre-Dame, as the book is called in English). Entry to the house is free, although there are fees to see special exhibitions.

It's okay but don't expect something super special. For me, Victor Hugo's personal bed and the painting in the same room showing Hugo's dead body on that bed and of course his famous portrait were the most interesting part.

I‚Äôm a huge fan of Les Mis√©rables, I have seen the musical so many times! We thought a visit to Maison de Victor Hugo would be a must do.  Going upstairs seeing the artwork was amazing, seeing some original books with screen printed artwork was a real treat.  Then going into seeing the house where Victor and his family lived with Victors writing desk with ink stains, blotting paper and a cast of victors hand.  I love that I could step back in time at Victor Hugo‚Äôs House, living in Birmingham we are surrounded by history, my own town dates back to Neolithic times, with plenty of place from 1400‚Äôs But to go to Paris often, I love its history.

One of my favorite museum to visit while taking walk to the 4eme arrondissement of Paris city. Located just at the passage hall of Place des Vosges and it‚Äôs really beautifully preserved decorated and very classical.  You'll find out many important informations about Victor Hugo in here that you've never heard before, both when he was living and after he died.

This museum is tucked in the corner of the Place des Vosges which is worth walking around all four sides and sitting in the park to absorb the buildings' architecture.  The museum is an old house which does a great job at showing his life story, as well as the furnishings of the period.  There are only 4 rooms decorated in the style of the era but each room has a lot to see - paintings, other artwork, documents and decor. I didn‚Äôt know that Hugo was a poet, painter and draftsman in addition to author. In his middle age, there was a lot of political activity in France and Hugo was exiled for almost 20 years to the British isle of Guernsey. I had no idea about any of that so it was an educational visit as well as interesting.  Their cafe was good - they offer a few hot dishes each day, plus sandwiches, salads and desserts. I had penne w roast pumpkin, pine nuts and sage butter which was very tasty; and of course good bread.
I had wanted to visit Hugo's home for many years. It was exciting to see a hint of his world. I highly recommend
Had a lovely tour with Victor, very interesting home design and details in the museum. Cute courtyard in the middle for a coffee
It's a small museum house of Victor Hugo and one should visit it to know the history. It takes around ¬Ω-1 hour for the complete permanent exhibition tour.
Very nice place to visit. The Victor Hugo house is free of charge. It takes about 30 min to 1 hour to visit it. You can enjoy the nearby garden as well.
The entrance to the house is free, and there are a couple of floors with a lot to see. No need to book anything ahead of time.
An interesting place. I particularly enjoyed how they relate the content with the current Paris Olympics in one section. Be aware that most part‚Äôs introduction is French-only.

Nice small museum. Apartment rooms and permanent collection is free. Additional charge for exhibitions on another floor. Interesting for history of Victor Hugo, his time, and life then. Ornate and stylish place. Delightful cafe downstairs with courtyard seating.

This was on the list of the museums I wanted to visit and it did not disappoint. We visited on Wednesday morning and there were only a few people there. So it was easy to see everything without a crowd. The entry was free and it took us about 40 minutes to go through everything. The museums is located on the second floor. It features the original furnitures used by Victor Hugo‚Äôs family. Bold wall papers on each room. Also a great view from the windows.

Nice little museum in a beautiful area of Paris. I wish I‚Äôd downloaded the app beforehand so I could hear the audio commentary. But it was still nice to walk through the apartment and see how things would have looked while Hugo was there. I loved seeing the standing desk.
A tribute to an amazing author. This elegant home is filled with historic documents and photographs. Several rooms, richly decorated, show the comfortable lifestyle of Victor Hugo.

The museum is free to visit, which is a good thing as it does not cover a great deal of the writers life. First floor is a temporary exhibition, mostly art. Second floor was interesting to find some details of his life (parts that were in English). However, when compared to Alexander Dumas and Jules Verne museums offer far more insight into the author. However, as stated this is free and those are not. So therefore, it is a good place to visit in a pleasant location. The cafe inside the space seems to be decent.

So fancy, such a great location, a perfect little place for a man with such importance and what an honor to be able to see how he lived. He is art, you can see it all over, writing is more than art, its imagination and as Einstein famously once said, ‚Äú‚Ä¶Imagination is more important than knowledge. Knowledge is limited. Imagination encircles the world.‚Äù You can feel Victor Hugo‚Äôs presence, especially in his room, for he did write in the nude there and died there too. My favorite room was the Chinese style living room it was amazing. Every part of the house will take your breath away, it‚Äôs fantastically decorated and it exudes elegance.

The museum is an impressive place where you can discover a small part of personal objects, images from plays, photos of family members and unique paintings.  It is the house where Victor Hugo lived for a while. The entry is free.

If you enjoy small museums that you can visit in 1h or less, this is for you. The museum is inside the house where (for some time) lived Victor Hugo. It's full of paintings and artefacts that depict the life of a famous writer and painter and his family. I do recommend spending 15mins or so reading an illustrated biography that's on the TV in the entrance hall, especially if you don't know much about him, or if you haven't read about his life beforehand. Entrance is free. There weren't many people. Employees check your bags before entrance and you go through the metal detector.

Free entrance to the museum and it's worth a visit. There's also a cafe on the ground floor with alfresco concept. I was however warned by the security personnel to carry my backpack on my front instead in the museum . So beware of pickpockets üòâ

An interesting and surprising experience to visit Victor Hugo's apartment.  It must be said that he is not only a writer but also a collector.  The apartment is filled with exquisite antiques.  There is a room with an Asian twist. You will not need to buy a ticket when visiting the apartment.  This is a fun experience that I recommend you do when you come to Paris.

Beautiful exhibition of the original apartment where Victor Hugo lived and worked for a number of years and we are so grateful that this was open to public free of charge. Small, intimate and worth a visit.

A Charming Journey through Victor Hugo's Life  4/5 Stars: I had a lovely time exploring Maison de Victor Hugo in Paris, a beautiful tribute to the famous writer's life and work. From the moment I stepped inside, I was struck by the cozy and intimate ambiance of the place, which perfectly matched the spirit of Hugo's romanticism.  The staff was welcoming and knowledgeable, providing me with useful information about the exhibitions and the house itself. I appreciated the effort put into the displays, which were creative and informative, featuring various original manuscripts, letters, and paintings. The house itself was a delight to behold, with its elegant architecture and period furniture, giving me a sense of stepping back in time.  However, I must admit that there were some downsides to the experience. One complaint I had was the limited amount of space for visitors, which made it difficult to move around during peak hours. Additionally, some of the displays were not well-lit, making it hard to read the texts or fully appreciate the artworks.  Despite these minor issues, I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to Maison de Victor Hugo and would recommend it to anyone interested in French literature or history. The place offers a unique perspective on the life and times of one of France's most celebrated writers, and its charm is sure to win over even the most skeptical visitor.  If I could offer any suggestions for improvement, it would be to provide more seating areas for visitors and to improve the lighting in certain areas of the exhibition. Overall, I am grateful for the opportunity to have visited Maison de Victor Hugo and would love to return in the future.  I would highly recommend this place to anyone looking for an immersive and engaging experience in the heart of Paris. With its cozy atmosphere, informative exhibitions, and rich historical context, Maison de Victor Hugo is sure to leave a lasting impression on anyone who visits.

so absolutely worth the visit. i was particularly impressed by the chinese drawing room. it showcases very thoughtful and unique designs of chinese furniture, cabinet and artworks that hugo made himself. never expected this at his house! the virtual tour on his gurnesey house downstairs was also very informative.
Walking inside an 19th century Parisian apartment is always a pleasure. Discover this unique French author by walking through the rooms he once used and lived at.
Another free museum in Paris. His former apartment is well kept. I had the most amazing cake in the museum Cafe and I managed to charge my dying phone there.

The museum is in the Place des Vosges (3rd and 4th arrondissement of Paris) and that alone makes it worth the visit! Hugo lived there between 1832 and 1848 with his family, in the sw corner of the Place des Vosges (then called the Place Royale). He composed some of his most acclaimed literary works there, including Les Mis√©rables, and entertained and debated literary contemporaries such as Alfred de Vigny and Alexandre Dumas. The museum is FREE (permanent exhibitions) only. It was recently renovated, and includes a collection of Hugo‚Äôs personal artifacts, furniture, manuscripts, hundred of letters and photographs, offering an intimate glimpse into the author‚Äôs inner life and intellectual exchanges.

One of my favorite places in Paris!  Absolutely worth to visit ‚Äî I highly recommend to everyone. Doesn‚Äôt matter if you know the author well or not, just the ambience is already very special and worth to see :)
When the weather is not that generous is a good way to spend a day indoor and get transported in V Hugo world. A plus the museum is completely free,  however advisable to donate.

It is a glimpse into the life of Victor Hugo.  Well curated.  One comment is to reflect better lighting to see the paintings.  Overall a very good space to visit while in Paris.  The neighborhood is host to spectacular art galleries.

Although this museum is free, it is unrated as many people deem it too small. But I feel that this apartment where he last lived is such a privilege to enter into the workings of Victor Hugo‚Äôs mind. Yes, he is renowned for his writings but his drawings, paintings and sculptures displayed are also to marvel at. Especially curious was towards his interior decor of the place. The asiatic room was his interpretation of the oriental, it is inspired from Asia but still holds its own character.

Victor Hugo lived in an apartment located at 6 Place des Vosges in Paris from 1832 to 1848, where he wrote some of his most famous works. Today, the apartment is a museum called the Maison de Victor Hugo, which is free to visit and showcases many of his personal possessions and original manuscripts.

Really good location, entrance is for free. Gives you an opportunity to look closer at live of this talented person. Inspires a lot, rooms has so much interesting and unique pieces. I highly recommend! Building itself is really old but charming as well.
Nice place to visit, you may find interesting things about Hugo.  A bit disappointing that the shop doesn‚Äôt have book translated to English.
Wonderful place to visit for any Les Miserable fan
Nice place with nice reflections from the past. The writer‚Äôs personal taste turned his place into a monument. Worths a visit absolutely. Nice surroundings for walk too, especially in spring.

Nice place to visit . You can know more about Victor Hugo and his life. You can feel him more. There is a great garden inside the mansion and a shop selling cake and coffee. Nice place to take a rest. Free entry and free toilet.

So glad we came, it's small and manageable but also poignant and beautiful, best of all, no crowds, no queues and it's free.  The square is also very charming and we had an excellent lunch around the corner at L'Angue 20.
